did.abstract: Myron Ezra Wegman, 1908-2004, was a leader in public health and clinical pediatrics for seven decades. The collection consists of personal and professional papers covering his career in medicine and public health and includes correspondence, reports, speeches, travel diaries, course material, reprints, and minutes and notes on organizations to which he belonged.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Professor Myron Wegman (donor no. 7585). The papers were received in multiple accessions: 1988, 1997, and 2004.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Myron E. Wegman Papers , Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Myron Wegman, Dean of the University of Michigan School of Public Health from 1960 to 1974 and Professor of Pediatrics and Communicable Diseases in the Medical School was born on July 23, 1908 in Brooklyn, New York. He was educated at the City College of New York (BA 1928), Yale University (MD 1932), and Johns Hopkins University (MPH, 1938).

His career began in 1936 with the Maryland State Health Department, Bureau of Child Hygiene. He spent a year, 1941-1942, at the School of Tropical Health in San Juan, Puerto Rico and then worked at the New York City Health Department while teaching part time at Johns Hopkins University, Columbia, and Cornell. In 1946 he took the position of professor and head of Pediatrics for Louisiana State University Medical School. From 1952 to 1960, Wegman held several positions in the World Health Organization (WHO), including chief of education and training, secretary-general, and consultant to the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO).

When Wegman became Dean of the University of Michigan School of Public Health in 1960, he was a well-established figure in the field of public health and a respected specialist in child health care. Wegman's work reflects a concern for the best possible health care for the greatest number of people, a position which was cause for worry for many administrators and medical care professionals because it implied a substantial financial commitment and institutional restructuring. While at the University of Michigan, Wegman served on the Commission on the Reduction of Excess Hospital Capacity. Here he was given the difficult task of targeting hospitals for bed reduction. Dr. Wegman also headed the push to implement HMOs at the university, a proposal vigorously resisted by administrators.

Dr. Wegman served on numerous committees and boards, often assisting with project implementation. He was one of the developers of Project HEADSTART. He helped to develop three health planning organizations; he was President of the Comprehensive Health Planning Council of Southeastern Michigan and member of the Michigan State Public Health Advisory Council. He was active in the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Board of Preventative Medicine, and the American Medical Association among other health organizations. His annual reports on world infant mortality in the journal Pediatrics from 1950 to 1997, gave him international repute as an authority on child health.

Among the many honors he received during his career were: the Sedgwick Medal, the highest award of the American Public Health Association, Man of the Year from the City College of New York, the Clifford G. Grulee Medal from the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Bronfman Prize from the American Public Health Association. On his eightieth birthday, the Myron E. Wegman Endowed Scholarship Fund was begun in tribute to his many professional accomplishments.

In retirement with emeritus status, Wegman pursued many professional activities as a consultant, public speaker, and advisor. In 1990 he was coordinator for the university's collaboration with the Autonomous University of Madrid. He died April 12, 2004.

scopecontent.p: The Myron Ezra Wegman collection is divided into seven series: Biographical and Early Materials, 1939-2004, University of Michigan, 1960-1988, Comprehensive Health Planning Organizations, 1968-1979, Associations, Committees, and Projects, 1949-1990, Post-Retirement Period, 1974-1993, Reprints, 1930-1989, and Topical Files.

controlaccess.corpname: Commission on Reduction of Excess Hospital Capacity in Southeastern Michigan.
Comprehensive Health Planning Council of Southeastern Michigan.

Medical care.
controlaccess.corpname: Michigan. Governor's Action Committee on Health Care.
University of Michigan. School of Public Health.

scopecontent.p: Biographical and Early Materials, 1939-2004 contains correspondence, reports, and teaching materials evidence of Wegman's career before joining the faculty of the University of Michigan. Of particular note are the materials from a 1949 protest against the medical profession, which resulted in Wegman's dismissal from a lecturing appointment in Arkansas. The incident gained national attention. The series is arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: "Protest Against Present Attitudes." and Arkansas School of Medicine

odd.p: (Johns Hopkins University, Maryland State Health Department, School of Tropical Health, Louisiana State University)

did.unittitle: WHO Study, Infant Diarrhea in Fin

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan, 1960-1988 series is comprised of committee files, course materials for the School of Public Health, correspondence and memoranda reflecting some educational and administrative concerns. Here there is Wegman's' study of a possible Health Maintenance Organization for the University, which is an early version of the HMO subsequently adopted. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Committee to Assess Periodic Health Appraisal Unit (PHAU)
Department of Health Planning and Administration
Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) study for University of Michigan

scopecontent.p: The third series is Comprehensive Health Planning Organizations, 1968-1979. Through minutes, memoranda, reports, and correspondence, this group documents the development, activities, concerns, and recommendations of three health planning organizations with which Wegman was intimately involved.: the Areawide Health Operating Committee, 1969-1970, the Comprehensive Health Planning Council of Southeastern Michigan, 1971-1979, and Community Health Incorporated, 1968-1973. These organizations made recommendations regarding proposed health facilities and worked with existing community health organizations, helping them to respond productively to health care needs.

did.unittitle: Transition to Comprehensive Health Planning Council

scopecontent.p: Associations, Committees, and Projects, 1949-1990 is a large series comprised of correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, and some reference materials. Among the groups documented here are the unpopular Commissions of Reduction of Excess Hospital Capacity, 1977-1980, the Governor's Action Committee on Health Care, 1964-1966, Project HEADSTART, and several seminars. The "Seminar on the Rational Uses of Medicine, 1974-1978, was concerned with supporting legislation regarding adequate drug labeling on medicines in other countries and responsible advertising. A large part of this series is devoted to Wegman's activities in WHO, 1950-1991, including travel diaries which are descriptive narratives on his many foreign assignments with WHO, as well as other trips abroad. This series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

odd.p: (including Switzerland, 1950, Cuba, 1975, South America, 1976, Brazil, 1981 and three trips to China)

scopecontent.p: The fifth series is the Post-Retirement Period, 1974-1993. Here the researcher will find extensive correspondence reflective of Wegman's numerous activities and travels primarily in a professional capacity. He was very active in the National Fellows Program funded by the Kellogg Foundation. Wegman kept this separate post-retirement correspondence file, dealing with many of his interests, particularly the University of Michigan and the World Health Organization.

did.unittitle: National Academy of Sciences, Pesticide Information Review and Evaluation Committee (PIREC)

scopecontent.p: Reprints, 1930-1989 series contains publications for Wegman's entire career. A full publications list can be found in the Biographical folder in Box 1.

did.unittitle: Brennemann's Practice of Pediatrics, Chapter 7, Community Aspects of Child Health

scopecontent.p: Topical Files series was originally arranged in alphabetical order with classification of folders by state or country. For ease of research the folders are filed by actual topic in most cases. This series represents, for the most part, post-retirement activities, many of them continuous from before Wegman's retirement.

John Sparkman Center for International Public Health Education
